Issues.Title: ToolTips in popups (or any context where capture is active) (#5931)
Issues.Body:
Fixes #5716

### Description
The new 6.0 tooltip behavior computes a "safe area" in which the user can move the mouse without dismissing the tooltip. It's computed with coordinates relative to the owner's PresentationSource (hwnd), but the mouse movements were tracked relative to the input provider's PresentationSource. These are often the same, but not when the tooltip's owner comes from a Popup (or similar context that captures mouse input away from the normal input provider). This dismisses the tooltip immediately - the logic thinks the mouse has left the safe area.

Fixed by converting the mouse position to the correct coordinate system - relative to the tooltip owner's PresentationSource.

### Customer Impact
Fixes a regression.

### Regression
Yes.

### Testing
### Risk
Low. Applies the correct coordinate transformation before checking the mouse position.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "ToolTips in popups (or any context where capture is active) (#5931)" (#6045)

Issues.Title: Use generic Marshal.StructureToPtr
Issues.Body:
## Description
Use generic Marshal.StructureToPtr instead of the non-generic. I removed the customs UnsafeNativeMethods.StructureToPtr which justs forwards to Marshal.StructureToPtr because it causes linker warnings because Marshal.StructureToPtr is annotated while UnsafeNativeMethods.StructureToPtr isn't.

Almost every call to Marshal.StructureToPtr were already using the generic overload without the need to change the code.

Contributes to #3811

## Customer Impact
None, same behavior as the non-generic.

## Regression
No

## Testing
I manually tested a few of the generic and non-generic and they gave the same result.

## Risk
None, same behavior as the non-generic.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Use generic Marshal.StructureToPtr" (#6044)

Issues.Title: . NET6 WPF: ToolTip doesn't work on ComboBoxItem
Issues.Body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/NET6-WPF:-ToolTip-doesnt-work-on-Combo/1648606)._ --- [severity:It bothers me. A fix would be nice] In WPF of .NET 6, the tooltip of the ComboBoxItem doesn't work if the ComboBox is inside of a UserControl. Actual behavior: the tooltip shows up for about 500ms and then it disappears. Expected behavior: the tooltip gets displayed for a reasonable amount of time. Note: _Setting explicitly the 'ToolTipService.ShowDuration' doesn't help._ Environment: Visual Studio Professional 2022 64-bit 17.0.5, .NET 6.0.1, Windows 10 Pro Version:21H1 I enclosed a project file that shows the issue: [TooTipTest.zip] (https://aka.ms/dc/file?name=B054640530ce04d1181db74af20165109637788677425623620_TooTipTest.zip&tid=054640530ce04d1181db74af20165109637788677425623620) I also inline the XAML for clarity. Issues.Title: Editing for DataGrid cell is not triggered while pressing any characters in keyboard only for some set of languages
Issues.Body:
In WPF DataGrid, if we select a cell and press any key, editing for that cell is triggered properly when the selected language in language preferences option in Windows 10 is English. 

If we select Tamil, then the cell doesn't enter edit mode when pressing any character in the key. 

Please refer to the attached video illustration of the problem and provide if there is any way to resolve this.


[DataGrid_EditDemo.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/files/7970881/DataGrid_EditDemo.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Editing for DataGrid cell is not triggered while pressing any characters in keyboard only for some set of languages" (#6041)

Issues.Title: BadImageFormatException happens when application is launching
Issues.Body:
I have found a very strange exception:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22408851/151691570-b534671c-e9fe-40cb-aac6-4d79ef772a6e.png)

This exception is thrown when the application launches.
And my code is like this:

```
    class Program
    {
        [STAThread]
        static void Main(string[] arg)
        {
            var splash = new SplashWindow();
            splash.Show();

            App application = new App();
            application.InitializeComponent();
            application.Run();
        }
    }
```
```
<Window>
    <Grid>
        <Grid.Background>
            <VisualBrush  Stretch="UniformToFill">
                <VisualBrush.Visual>
                    <Grid Width="{StaticResource DefaultResolutionWidth}" Height="{StaticResource DefaultResolutionHeight}">
                        <Image x:Name="imageWatermark"
                        Width="{StaticResource SplashLogoWidth}"
                        Height="{StaticResource SplashLogoHeight}"
                        Source="{DynamicResource MainWindowWatermark}" />
                    </Grid>
                </VisualBrush.Visual>
            </VisualBrush>
        </Grid.Background>
    </Grid>
</Window>
```

This exception only happened once, and cannot reproduce.

I'm not sure the reason is that I show a Window of WPF before the Application construct?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "BadImageFormatException happens when application is launching" (#6033)

Issues.Title: NETFX 4.8.1: Arm64 compiled WPF applications attempt to load x64 wpfgfx_v0400.dll
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: N/A
* Windows version: Windows 11 22543.1000 Arm64
* Does the bug reproduce also in WPF for .NET Framework 4.8?: Yes. 4.8.9014.0
* Is this bug related specifically to tooling in Visual Studio (e.g. XAML Designer, Code editing, etc...)? No
* Security issues and bugs should be reported privately, learn more via our [responsible disclosure guidelines](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/main/README.md#reporting-security-issues-and-security-bugs).

 **Problem description:**
 Creating a blank WPF application targeting .NET Framework 4.8 and compiled for Arm64 will crash when loading the WpfGfx native library. 

 **Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->

The NativeWPFDLLLoader in PresentationCore.dll incorrectly tries to load the wpfgfx_v0400.dll from `Framework64 `instead of `FrameworkArm64`. 

<details><summary>Stack Trace from debugging in dnSpy</summary>

```

   --- End of inner exception stack trace ---
   at MS.Internal.NativeWPFDLLLoader.LoadNativeWPFDLL(UInt16* relDllPath, UInt16* baseDllPath)
   at MS.Internal.NativeWPFDLLLoader.LoadCommonDLLsAndDwrite()
   at CModuleInitialize.{ctor}(CModuleInitialize* , IntPtr cleaningUpFunc)
   at ?A0xe5657cc7.InitCmiStartupRunner()
   at ?A0xe5657cc7.??__E?A0xe5657cc7@unused@@YMXXZ()

   at <CrtImplementationDetails>.LanguageSupport._Initialize(LanguageSupport* )
   at <CrtImplementationDetails>.LanguageSupport.Initialize(LanguageSupport* )}
```
</details>

 **Minimal repro:**

1. Create a blank WPF (.NET Framework) application in Visual Studio 2022 (probably even 2019)
2. Edit .csproj to change Platform to arm64, or manually build project with msbuild and set /platform:arm64. 
3. Run generated executable on an Arm64 device and reproduce crash behavior.

Issues.Title: Exception "The data area passed to a system call is too small"
Issues.Body:
### Description

Encountered the below exception stack trace in our production WPF application.

Details are scant but I do know the PC was running Windows 10 Pro 2009, and the version of our software that was running targeted net6.0-windows runtime environment. I also have a list of processes that were currently running at the time of the exception. I'm not sure how to share that privately here; let me know if you need it and I'll arrange a way.

It's difficult to tell exactly what the state of our software was when this exception happened, but other than this exception all signs indicate the software was operating normally.

Here's the stack trace:
```
Type: System.ComponentModel.Win32Exception
Message: The data area passed to a system call is too small.
Source: WindowsBase
Stack Trace:
at MS.Win32.UnsafeNativeMethods.GetWindowText(HandleRef hWnd, StringBuilder lpString, Int32 nMaxCount)
at System.Windows.Automation.Peers.WindowAutomationPeer.GetNameCore()
at System.Windows.Automation.Peers.AutomationPeer.UpdateSubtree()
at System.Windows.ContextLayoutManager.fireAutomationEvents()
at System.Windows.ContextLayoutManager.UpdateLayout()
at System.Windows.ContextLayoutManager.UpdateLayoutCallback(Object arg)
at System.Windows.Media.MediaContext.FireInvokeOnRenderCallbacks()
at System.Windows.Media.MediaContext.RenderMessageHandlerCore(Object resizedCompositionTarget)
at System.Windows.Media.MediaContext.RenderMessageHandler(Object resizedCompositionTarget)
at System.Windows.Threading.ExceptionWrapper.InternalRealCall(Delegate callback, Object args, Int32 numArgs)
at System.Windows.Threading.ExceptionWrapper.TryCatchWhen(Object source, Delegate callback, Object args, Int32 numArgs, Delegate catchHandler)
```

Internet search results currently point to some issue with an out-of-date installation of SQL Server. I do not believe SQL Server is/was present on this machine.

### Reproduction Steps

Sorry

### Expected behavior

I expect no exception

### Actual behavior

Above exception was thrown

### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

_No response_

### Configuration

Windows 10 Pro 2009
x64
WPF
net6.0-windows target

### Other information

_No response_

Issues.Title: Should we remove the PresentationFramework.Luna.dll
Issues.Body:
As we all know, the PresentationFramework.Luna.dll is the Windows XP theme assembly. But we no longer support Windows XP.

Should we remove the PresentationFramework.Luna.dll to save the size?

- PresentationFramework.Luna.dll   643.60KB

Ref: https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/3265
